data.text: @charliegiattino @OurWorldInData Yes, thank you for asking. I find it very pronounced in the U.S. with some other nations showing it, but it's not consistent globally. https://t.co/LvIMkxFh5r
@nareshkumarmph @OurWorldInData You mean the 0–14 yrs age group here (https://t.co/T3e4NnO4s5)? For which countries do you see it?

@charliegiattino @OurWorldInData Any insight into the recent steep decline in the lowest age group?

Delays in reporting or a true signal or some combination of the two?
@charliegiattino @OurWorldInData Ah, I'm sorry, I must've misread - I thought the heading said "previous year", not "previous years"

@strangeglyph @OurWorldInData I'm not sure I follow what you say. It's the weekly reported deaths during the pandemic (2020–2022) compared to a projection for those same years; the projection is based on the years 2015–2019.
@charliegiattino @OurWorldInData Is excess mortality compared to previous year such a useful metric several years into the pandemic? Wouldn't excess mortality compared to 2019 be more useful?
@charliegiattino @OurWorldInData Sure makes you realize what happened to countries that had the “let it rip” mentality over those that followed science to contain the spread and reduce death.
